qas.question: To what extent does wealth reach from affluent down to average population?
Who do Egyptians blame for higher prices, while purchasing power and standard of living are stagnate?
Where did Egyptian plan to get funds to use for reconstruction of infrastructure?

answers.text: newly acquired third mobile license ($3 billion) by Etisalat

qas.question: Where did Egypt rank in Corruption perceptions Index in 2013?

context: Although one of the main obstacles still facing the Egyptian economy is the <a0_0>limited trickle down<a0_0/> of wealth to the average population, many Egyptians criticise their <a1_0>government<a1_0/> for higher prices of basic goods while their standards of living or purchasing power remains relatively stagnant. Corruption is often cited by Egyptians as the main impediment to further economic growth. The government promised major reconstruction of the country's infrastructure, using money paid for the <a2_0>newly acquired third mobile license ($3 billion) by Etisalat<a2_0/> in 2006. In the Corruption Perceptions Index 2013, Egypt was ranked <a3_0>114 out of 177<a3_0/>.
